docs.lead_paragraph: Funny Cide is up for the rematch with Empire Maker in the 134th running of the Travers Stakes on Saturday. Or is he? Empire Maker is ready to show that his runaway defeat of Funny Cide in the Belmont Stakes was no fluke. Or will his stablemate, Peace Rules, take his place in the starting gate for the Travers?

headline.main: Trainers Play Game Of Poker At Travers

docs.abstract: Trainer Barclay Tagg enters Funny Cide and trainer Bobby Frankel enters Empire Maker and Peace Rules in Travers Stakes, even though both trainers have said previously that their horses may not run; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Medicare will begin paying for a major lung operation for certain people 65 and over who have severe emphysema with specific traits that make them likely to benefit from the surgery, the government announced yesterday. The operation, lung volume reduction surgery, involves cutting away diseased parts of the lungs to help the remaining healthy tissue work better. As much as 30 percent of the lungs may be removed. The operation costs about $60,000.

headline.main: Medicare to Pay for Major Lung Operation

docs.abstract: Medicare will begin paying for major lung operation for certain people 65 and over who have severe emphysema with specific traits that make them likely to benefit from surgery; operation, lung volume reduction surgery, costs $60,000; private insurers and state Medicaid programs generally follow Medicare's example (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cracks appeared yesterday in a pillar of drug industry profits with twin announcements that users of a huge-selling heartburn drug will soon have alternatives that will be cheaper and easier to buy. As a result, the biggest fight ever seen between managed-care companies and drug makers could soon begin. In the first announcement, Novartis said it would soon start selling omeprazole, the generic version of Prilosec, even though a court has yet to approve the sale. The aggressive move could open Novartis to huge damages if a judge eventually ruled that its generic version infringed patents owned by AstraZeneca, which sells Prilosec. But it also means that consumers will soon save a bundle on the medicine. Prilosec currently sells for $116 for a month's supply on Drugstore.com. A lone generic version introduced in December sells for $100; with more generic entries, analysts said the price could drop to $11.

headline.main: 2 New Fronts in Heartburn Market Battle

docs.abstract: Novartis says it will soon start selling heartburn drug omeprazole, generic version of Prilosec, even though court has yet to approve sale; aggressive move could open Novartis to huge damages if judge eventually rules that its generic version infringes patents owned by AstraZeneca, which sells Prilosec; Procter & Gamble Co says it will begin selling over-the-counter version of Prilosec on Sept 15, priced about 70 cents per pill, or $22 or so for month's supply (M)
docs.snippet: Cracks appeared yesterday in a pillar of drug industry profits with twin announcements that users of a huge-selling heartburn drug will soon have alternatives that will be cheaper and easier to buy. As a result, the biggest fight ever seen between...

docs.lead_paragraph: In its early years, the small fleet of roving white ambulances with ''The Rock'' emblazoned on the side was a small but crucial community ambulance service, helping to rescue swimmers and serving the elderly and high-crime communities in the Rockaways. But the Rock Volunteer Ambulance Corps became known as a big-time responder, playing important rescue roles in major city emergencies like the World Trade Center attack and the crash of Flight 587 in Belle Harbor two months later. And in last week's blackout, the group rescued three elderly residents stranded in high-rise apartments.

headline.main: An Ambulance Corps in Need of Rescue

docs.abstract: Rock Volunteer Ambulance Corps has responded to terrorist attacks, plane crashes and other emergencies from its base in Rockaways in Queens, and now its leader, Rev Donald Ventura, seeks government aid to pay its outstanding bills; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: JACKSON--Joseph Hamilton. Born June 15, 1901 in East Orange, NJ. Died August 19, 2003 at home at age 102. Only child of B.G. Joseph Cook Jackson, Jr. Insurance executive of Hartford, CT; and Mabel Goodsell Jackson, newspaper reporter for the old Newark Evening News. Mr. Jackson was a worldwide traveller with his distinguished parents. He was a constant donor of various charities including the Jackson Cabin at Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys. He celebrated his 100th birthday in remarkable good health and received a letter of congratulations from President George W. Bush. Service at St. Marks Church, Westhampton Beach, NY, 11AM Friday, August 22. Interment at Cedar Hill Cemetery, Hartford, CT. One first cousin, Katharine Jackson Reese and numerous second cousins survive him. Contributions to St. Marks Episcopal Church, Main St, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths   JACKSON, JOSEPH HAMILTON

docs.lead_paragraph: When Dr. Rich Barbara signed up to test the iBOT -- Johnson & Johnson's stair-climbing wheelchair -- in the summer of 2001, he thought he would be reluctant to give it back at the end of the two-week trial. But impressed as he was with its balancing abilities, Dr. Barbara, a 50-year-old paraplegic, found himself yearning for his manual wheelchair. ''I was glad when my two weeks were up,'' said Dr. Barbara, a clinical psychologist at the University of Pittsburgh's Rehabilitation Hospital.

headline.main: Users Discover Pros and Cons In Stair-Climbing Wheelchair

docs.abstract: Independence iBOT 3000 Mobility System, stair climbing wheelchair able to navigate rough terrain and elevate user, wins approval from Food and Drug Administration; chair, designed by New Hampshire inventor Dean Kamen and produced by Johnson & Johnson, is reviewed by two-week trial user Dr Rich Barbara, who finds some aspects of new chair too cumbersome, outweighing benefits; financing of chair by insurance is discussed; other similar chairs described; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: John V. Lindsay's tenure was defined by strikes, the first one hitting only hours after he was sworn in. Edward I. Koch and Rudolph W. Giuliani started off talking tough, but ended up awarding hefty raises to municipal workers that left the city in a bind when recessions hit. David N. Dinkins squeezed some of the same unions that had helped elect him and then never got a chance to serve a second term. The success or failure of a New York City mayor, or at least his reputation as a leader or wimp, hinges in part on his finesse in handling labor negotiations. Now it is Michael R. Bloomberg's turn.

headline.main: Bloomberg and City Unions Draw the Lines, Far Apart

docs.abstract: Analysis of present municipal labor situation in New York City as Mayor Michael R Bloomberg and union leaders prepare for bargaining sessions; city wants concessions for pay increases, but union officials have mixed ideas about improving productivity and are reluctant to accept measures that just cut costs; diagram, photos (L)

byline.original: By ERIC LIPTON and STEVEN GREENHOUSE

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna, one of the biggest health insurers, plans to announce this morning that it has settled a lawsuit over billing practices with most of the nation's dentists. Both sides said they expected the settlement, which was signed on Friday, to improve relations and allow dentists to spend more time with patients and less time on paperwork.

headline.main: Aetna Settles Dentists' Suit Over Delays in Payments

docs.abstract: Health insurer Aetna plans to announce it has settled lawsuit over billing practices with most of nation's dentists; both sides expect settlement to improve relations and allow dentists to spend more time with patients and less time on paperwork; agreement involved 147,000 dentists, who are receive $4 million, or average of $80 to $100 for each of 40,000 to 50,000 who do business with Aetna; Aetna will also give $1 million to ADA Foundation, charitable arm of American Dental Association, and pay up to $1.25 million in lawyers' fees (M)
docs.snippet: Aetna, one of the biggest health insurers, plans to announce this morning that it has settled a lawsuit over billing practices with most of the nation's dentists.    Both sides said they expected the settlement, which was signed on Friday, to improve...

docs.lead_paragraph: Although few measures buy as much health for the money as vaccination, America's vaccine system is troubled. Millions of people cannot afford immunizations. In recent years, some vaccines have run short, and fewer companies produce them. In early August a panel appointed by the National Academy of Sciences advocated a sweeping reorganization of vaccine financing, arguing that it would make a dramatic difference in Americans' health. The dilemma is that vaccines are both too expensive and too cheap. One-fourth of children under age 2 do not get all their necessary vaccines, although cost is not the major reason since children normally have some type of vaccine coverage. The immunization rates for adults, who often lack insurance coverage, are far lower. At the same time, however, prices aren't high enough to persuade drug companies to make existing vaccines and find new ones. Only five companies produce vaccines today, compared with 25 three decades ago.
docs.abstract: Editorial backs recommendation by National Academy of Sciences for sweeping reorganization of vaccine financing, which urges government to get out of business of buying vaccines directly and instead use its money to help underwrite programs to broaden public access to vaccines
